title: Overcoming the frontiers of biomolecular studies on human history and adaptation using palaeoproteomics
descriptions:
The grant proposal titled "Overcoming the frontiers of biomolecular studies on human history and adaptation using palaeoproteomics" seeks to push the boundaries of biomolecular research in understanding human evolution and adaptation through the innovative application of palaeoproteomics. The project acronym BACKWARD outlines its key objectives of developing new palaeoproteomic workflows and utilizing advanced mass spectrometry and bioinformatic solutions.

The aims of the project include addressing African and Asian extinct hominid phylogeny, extending molecular-based phylogeny beyond ancient DNA limits, and reconstructing the evolutionary history of species extinct millions of years ago. By employing palaeoproteomics and mass spectrometry-based ancient protein sequencing, the project targets phylogenetic relationships among South African early hominins and hominid palaeobiodiversity in Southeast Asia.

The potential applications of this research are vast, including the identification of processes related to human brain expansion and reorganization, as well as species and sex identification from isolated fossil fragments. Furthermore, the project aims to have a commercial impact in areas such as forensic medicine, the food industry, and the pharmaceutical industry.

Through a collaborative effort among participating institutions, this project aims to have a transformative impact comparable to the revolution seen in ancient DNA research over the past two decades.
